availability.p: Copyright © 2018, Christopher Alan Mosher, Shelton, Connecticut, USA.
availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

Steuben County, ss.—
On this- -day of- -before uie personally
came- -Presideit of Harrison Cemetery Association, and
-Secretary of said Association, to me known wbo being duly
sworn, did depose and say, that they were such officers, and that they executed the annexed con
veyance, as such officers, and that the seal affixed thereto is the seal of such Association, and that
such conveyance is made by authority of said Association.

RULES AND CONDITIONS.
1. All Lots shall be held in pursuance of "Act, authorizing the incorporation of rural Cemetery Association,"
passed April 27, 1847; and of the incorporation of the HARRISON CEMETERY ASSOCIATION, under the
authority of the said Act on the 19th day of September, 1885, and shaii not be used for any other purpose, than
as a place of burial for the dead.
3, The proprietor of each lot shall have the right to enclose the same with any fence made wholly of iron, or
they may enclose the lot with a single railing of iron or white pine, or white oak, not to exceed three inches in
diameter, with posts of either of the foregoing material, and placed not less than seven feet apart, the railing
and posts to be pianed or turned, and kept heavily coated with paint. No other enclosure except such as above
designated, will be allowed, unless by permission of two-thirds of the Trustees, so long as the outside fence of
the cemetery is in good repair.
3. Any proprietor may seil and convey his lot at any time. But no such conveyance shali be valid until a_
certficate of such sale, statuig the names of the parties, and the consideration, signed and acknowledged by alf
the parties thereto, shall have been delivered to the secretary of the Association.
4. No disinterment shall be allowed without permission being obtained of the Secretary of the Association.
5. The proprietor of each lot shall have a right to erect any proper stones, monuments or sepulchral struct
ures thereon, and to cultivate trees, shrubs and plants in the same. But no tree growing within the lot or border
shaU be cut down or destroyed without the consent of the Trustees.
6. If any trees or shrubs, situated in any lot, shall by the means of their roots, branches or otherwise, become
detrimental to the adjacent lots or avenues, or d tngerous or inconvenient to passengers, or any tree or shrub
within the lines of any lot, which shall have been set out by the owner thereof, and then left neglected and not
properly trimmed or cultivated, it shall be the duty of the Trustees and they shall have the right to enter the
said lot and remove the said trees and shrubs, or such parts thereof as are detrimental, dangerous, inconvenient
or unsightly.
7. If any monument, effigy or enclosure, or any structure whatever, or any inscription be placed in or upon
any lot which shall be determined by the major part of the Trustees, for the time being, to be offensive or im
proper, or injurious to the appearance of surrounding lots or grounds, the said Trustees or a major part of them
shali have the right, and it shall be their duty to enter upon such lot and remove the said offensive or improper
object or objects.
8. The Board of Trustees from time to time,may lay out or alter such avenues or walk8,and make such rules and
regulations for the government of the grounds as they may redeem requisite and proper to to secure and pro
mote the general objects of the Cemetery.
9. The proprietors of lots and their families shall be allowed access to the grounds at all times; observing the
rules which are or may be adopted for the regulation of visitors.

RULES AND CONDITIONS.
1. All Lots shall be held in pursuance of "Act, authorizing the incorporation of rural Cemetery Association"
passed April 27, 1847; and of the incorporation of the HARRISON CEMETERY ASSOCIATION, under the
authority of the said Act on the 19th day of September, 1885, and shall not be used for any other purpose, than
as a place of burial for the dead.
2. The proprietor of each lot shall have the right to enclose the same with any fence made wholly of iron, or
they may enciose the lot with a single railing of iron or white pine, or white oak, not to exceed three inches in
diameter, with posts of either of the foregoing material, and placed not less than seven feet apart, the railing
and posts to be planed or turned, and kept heavily coated with paint. No other enclosure except such as above
designated, will be allowed, unless by permission of two-thirds of the Trustees, so long as the outside fence of
the cemetery is in good repair.
3. Any proprietor may sell and convey his lot at any time. But no such conveyance shall be valid until a
certflbate of such sale, stating the names of the partiesi-aard the consideration, signed and acknowledged by all-
the parties thereto, shall have been delivered to the secretary of the Association,
4. No disinterment shall be allowed without permission being obtained of the Secretary of the Association.
5. The proprietor of each lot shall have a right to erect any proper stones, monuments or sepulchral struct
ures thereon, and to cultivate trees, shrubs and plants in the same. But no tree growing within the lot or border
shall be cut down or destroyed without the consent of the Trustees.
0. If any trees or shrubs, situated in any lot, shall by the means of their roots, branches or otherwise, become
detrimental to the adjacent lots or avenues, or d tngerous or inconvenient to passengers, or any tree or shrub
within the lines of any lot, which shall have been set out by the owner thereof, and then left neglected and not
properly trimmed or cultivated, it shall be the duty of the Trustees and they shall have the right to enter the
said lot and remove the said trees and shrubs, or such parts thereof as are detrimental, dangerous, inconvenient
or unsightly.
7. If any monument, eiBgy or enclosure, or any structure whatever, or any inscription be placed in or upon
any lot which shall be determined by the major part of the Trustees, for the time being, to be offensive or im
proper, or injurious to the appearance of surrounding lots or grounds, the said Trustees or a major part of them
shall have the right, and it shall be their duty to enter upon such lot and remove the said offensive or improper
object or objects,
8. The Board of Trustees from time to time,raay lay out or alter such avenues or walks.and make such rules and
regulations for the government of the grounds as they may redeem requisite and proper to to secure and pro
mote the general objects of the Cemetery,
9. The proprietors of lots and their families shall be allowed access to the grounds at all times; observino-the
rules which are or may be adopted for the regulation of visitors. "

RULES AND CONDITIONS.
1. All Lots shall be held in pursuance of "Act, authorizing the incorporation of rural Cemetery Association "
passed April 27, 1847; and of the incorporation of the HARRISON CEMETERY ASSOCIATION, under the
authority of the said Act on the 19th day of September, 1885, and shall not be used for any other purpose, than
as a place of burial for the dead.
2. The proprietor of each lot shall have the right to enclose the same with any fence made wholiy of iron or
they may enclose the lot with a single railing of iron or white pine, or white oak, not to exceed three inches in
diameter, with posts of either of the foregoing material, and placed not less than seven feet apart, the railing
and posts to be planed or turned, and kept heavily coated with paint. No other enclosure except such as above
designated, will be allowed, unless by permission of two-thirds of the Trustees, so long as the outside fence of
the cemetery is in good repair.
3. Any proprietor may sell and convey his lot at any time. But no such conveyance shall 'be valid until a
certflcate of such sale, stating the names of the parties, and the consideration, signed and acknowledged by all
the parties thereto, shall have been delivered to the secretary of the Association.
4. No disinterment shall be allowed without permission being obtained of the Secretary of the Association.
5. The proprietor of each lot shall have a right to erect any proper stones, monuments or sepulchral struct
ures thereon, and to cultivate trees, shrubs and plants in the same. But no tree growing within the lot or border
shall be cut down or destroyed without the consent of the Trustees.
6. If any trees or shrubs, situated in any lot, shall by the means of their roots, branches or otherwise, become
detrimental to the adjacent lots or avenues, or dangerous or inconvenient to passengers, or any tree or shrub
within the lines of any lot, which shall have been set out by the owner thereof, and then left neglected and not
properly trimmed or cultivated, it shall be the duty of the Trustees and they shall have the right to enter the
said lot and remove the said trees and shrubs, or such parts thereof as are detrimental, dangerous, inconvenient
or unsightly.
7. If any monument, effigy or enclosure, or any structure whatever, or any inscription be placed in or upon
any lot which shall be determined by the major part of the Trustees, for the time being, to be offensive or im
proper, or injurious to the appearance of surrounding lots or grounds, the said Trustees or a major part of them
shall have the right, and it shall be their duty to enter upon such lot and remove the said offensive or improper
object or objects.
8. The Board of Trustees from time to time,raay lay out or alter such avenues or walks,and make such rules and
regulations for the government of the grounds as they may redeem requisite and proper to to secure and pro
mote the general objects of the Cemetery.
9. The proprietors of lots and their families shall be allowed access to the grounds at all times; observing the
rules which are or may be adopted for the regulation of visitors.
